body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1000^\\text{th}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" digit to the right of the decimal point in the decimal representation of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(1+\\sqrt{2})^{3000}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here's a rigorous solution to go along with Darryl Stein's nice observations."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Use the Binomial Theorem to write 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x = (1 + \sqrt{2})^{3000} = \sum_{i=0}^{3000} {3000 \choose i} \sqrt{2}^i "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Notice that the even terms in this sum are integers.
Notice that the binomial expansion of the "conjugate" expression, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y = (1 - \sqrt{2})^{3000}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the same thing, but with the odd terms negated:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" y = (1 - \sqrt{2})^{3000} = \sum_{i=0}^{3000} {3000 \choose i} (-\sqrt{2})^i "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Adding these formulae, the odd terms cancel, and we see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x + y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a (fairly large) integer!
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x + y = 2 \sum_{i = 0}^{1500} {3000 \choose 2i} 2^i"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Put another way, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are additive inverses (mod 1).
Interestingly, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are also multiplicative inverses (over the reals), since
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" (1 + \sqrt{2})(1 - \sqrt{2}) = 1 - 2 = -1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"-1^{3000} = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"; however, we will not need this fact."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Next we will show that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0 < y < 10^{-1000} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
and hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s 1000'th digit after the decimal place is 0.  Equivalently,
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0 < (\sqrt{2} - 1)^3 < \frac{1}{10} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
which follows because "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \sqrt{2} < \frac{10}{7} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \left( \frac{3}{7}\right) ^3 = \frac{27}{343} < \frac{1}{10} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Finally, since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are additive inverses (mod 1), and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has a 0 in its 1000'th decimal digit, 
and some nonzeros in later decimal digits, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must have a 9 in its 1000'th decimal digit.  Here we also
used the fact that both "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are positive."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 + "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sqrt2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is known as the silver ratio and is a Pisot–Vijayaraghavan number, which has the property that higher powers are closer and closer to an integer."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For very high powers of a PV number the resultant number will look like either."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n.99999999999999..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"or"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n.00000000000000..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By inspection of the first few powers of the silver ratio we can see that odd powers are slightly above an integer and even powers are slightly below an integer."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, since the power is even (3000) the number will look like"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n.9999999999999999..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"and the power 3000 is sufficient to make the 9's continue past the 1000th digit of the result - therefore the answer is 9."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So 1000 is part of the way into the 45th row of the triangle.

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We then use the quadratic formula and take the positive solution to get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n \approx \frac{1+3\sqrt{889}}{2}\approx 44 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (note that even though we have taken "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lfloor \sqrt{889} \rfloor"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" along with our original approximation of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\binom{n+1}{2}\approx 1000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the second approximation does not affect the first and vice versa, meaning our approximation is still accurate.) "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"in row 1000, we have 1000 integers (1,2,3,...,1000)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, take the number of integers in row n to form an arithmetic progression (AP)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AP: 1,2,3,...,1000"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"To determine the row of 1000th number, "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S <= 1000"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(n/2) [2a+(n-1)d] <=1000"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(n/2) [2x1+(n-1)1] <=1000"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(n/2) (2+n-1) <=1000"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(n/2) (n+1) <=1000"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n^2+n<=2000"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n^2+n-2000<=0"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=44.23 or -45.22"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n denotes the number of row, so n cannot b negative, therefore n=44.23"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This n value represents 1000th number is in the 45th row"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"To determine where the 1000th number in the 45th row, substitute n=44 into "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(n/2) (n+1)=990"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1000-990=10 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The 1000th number is the 10th element in the 45th row, therefore the 1000th number is 10"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First: we find the row contains the 1000th term

n = 44, so the 1000th term in group 44 + 1 = 45"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Second: max value of group 44 is 44*45/2 = 990
then in group 45, the value of 1000th is 10 (because 1000 - 990 = 10)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The number of consecutive positive quadratic residues mod "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that are less than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{p-5}4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" if "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p \equiv 1 \pmod 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{p-3}4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" if "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p \equiv 3 \pmod 4."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" So the answer is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{7919-3}4 = \fbox{1979}."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"To prove the general statement about quadratic residues, let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the number of consecutive quadratic residues. Then consider
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
\sum_{x=1}^{p-1} \left( \left( \frac{x}{p} \right) + 1 \right) \left( \left( \frac{x+1}{p} \right) + 1 \right).
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Here "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left( \frac{\cdot}{\cdot} \right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the "},{"type":"text","text":"Legendre symbol","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"When "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are both quadratic residues, we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" When one of them is a nonresidue, we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" There is one more case: when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=p-1,"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left( \frac{-1}{p} \right) + 1."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" So the conclusion is that
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
4C + 1 + \left( \frac{-1}{p} \right) = \sum_{x=1}^{p-1} \left( \left( \frac{x}{p} \right) + 1 \right) \left( \left( \frac{x+1}{p} \right) + 1 \right).
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Expanding the sum on the right gives
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
4C + 1 + \left( \frac{-1}{p} \right) = \sum_{x=1}^{p-1} \left( \frac{x}{p} \right) \left( \frac{x+1}{p} \right) + \sum_{x=1}^{p-1} \left( \frac{x}{p} \right) + \sum_{x=1}^{p-1} \left( \frac{x+1}{p} \right) + (p-1).
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
The second term is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0,"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" because there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{p-1}2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" residues and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{p-1}2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" nonresidues. The third term is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"-1,"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" because it is the same as the second term, except that it replaces "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left(\frac1{p} \right) = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left(\frac{p}{p} \right) = 0."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" Bringing everything to the left side gives
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
4C + 3 - p + \left( \frac{-1}{p} \right) = \sum_{x=1}^{p-1} \left( \frac{x}{p} \right) \left( \frac{x+1}{p} \right) = \sum_{x=1}^{p-1} \left( \frac{x^2+x}{p} \right).
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
But 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
\left(\frac{x^2+x}{p}\right) = \left(\frac{x^2}{p}\right)\left(\frac{1+x^{-1}}{p}\right) = \left(\frac{1+x^{-1}}{p}\right).
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
As "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ranges from "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p-1,"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" so does "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^{-1},"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y=1+x^{-1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ranges from "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" We get
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
4C + 3 - p + \left( \frac{-1}{p} \right) = \sum_{x=1}^{p-1} \left( \frac{1+x^{-1}}{p} \right) = \sum_{y=2}^p \left( \frac{y}{p} \right) = -1.
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
So
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
4C = p-4-\left( \frac{-1}{p} \right),
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
which gives the result we had claimed."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
